title: UK Government Sees £1.3bn Surplus For July
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Fri, Aug 21, 2015, 18:45 BST - UK Markets closed UK Government Sees £1.3bn Surplus For July By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 2 hours 12 minutes ago View Photo 

The Government earned more than it spent in July, meaning the public finances were in surplus by £1.3bn for the month. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is the first time the country has been in the black since 2012. 
One of the biggest contributors was a major boost in the amount of income tax - total revenues were £18.5bn, the highest since 1997. 
The surplus compares to a borrowing of £100m for the same month in 2014. 
According to the figures, released by the Office for National Statistics, average borrowing for the financial year to date stands at £24bn. 
That represents a drop of 23.3%, or £7.3bn, from the same period last year. 
Although it is likely to help the Chancellor's rhetoric that the economy is in good hands, the figure was slightly less than expected and still a long way off pre-recession surplus levels of around £3bn. 
Underlying public sector net debt had dropped slightly since June to £1.51tn, or 80% of GDP, but this was a higher percentage than July 2014 when it was 79.7% (£1.43tn). 
The Chancellor said: "With more tax coming in this month than the Government spent, borrowing so far is almost £7.5bn lower than last year." 
"The recovery is well established, tax revenues are up and we have more than halved the deficit. 
"But with debt over 80% of GDP, the job is not done." 
Investec (LSE: INVP.L - news ) 's Victoria Clarke said: "This evidence of a steady narrowing in the deficit will clearly do Mr Osborne no harm in continuing to argue that his fiscal plans are working. 
"Further, as the Government moves full swing into work on the impending Spending Review, this may help Mr Osborne in pushing his fiscal cause, as he faces off his colleagues in tough talks over spending settlements (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) ."
